questions.question: What notation indicates a discrete-time signal?
questions.explanation: Brackets [n] indicate discrete-time. Parentheses (t) indicate continuous-time.

questions.question: A continuous-time signal is defined for:
questions.explanation: CT signals are defined for all real values of the independent variable t.

questions.question: What is the Nyquist sampling rate for a 10 kHz signal?
questions.explanation: Nyquist rate = 2 × maximum frequency = 2 × 10 kHz = 20 kHz.

questions.question: Aliasing occurs when:
questions.explanation: Aliasing occurs when sampling below Nyquist rate, causing high frequencies to fold back.

questions.question: An ADC converts:
questions.explanation: An Analog-to-Digital Converter (ADC) converts continuous-time signals to discrete-time.

questions.question: CD audio uses 44.1 kHz sampling because:
options: Human hearing is up to ~20 kHz
questions.explanation: 44.1 kHz > 2×20 kHz, satisfying Nyquist for the ~20 kHz human hearing limit.

questions.question: In discrete-time, what replaces integration?
questions.explanation: Summation (Σ) in DT corresponds to integration (∫) in CT.

questions.question: The value x[1.5] for a discrete signal is:
questions.explanation: Discrete signals are only defined at integer indices. x[1.5] is undefined, not zero.

questions.question: What component prevents aliasing?
questions.explanation: An anti-aliasing (lowpass) filter removes frequencies above Nyquist before sampling.

questions.question: Ts in sampling represents:
questions.explanation: Ts is the sampling period — the time between consecutive samples.
